e21.sweet16.loader module¶

class e21.sweet16.loader.Loader(**kw)[source]¶

Bases: object

A sweet16 file loader.

E.g. loading a susceptibility measurement:

>>>from e21.sweet16 import Loader
>>>s16 = Loader(mode='susceptibility')
>>>measurement = s16('path/to/susceptibility_measurement.dat')
CREATOR = {'susceptibility': <function create at 0x2ab1e8304c80>, 'transport': <function create at 0x2ab1e831f1b8>}¶
parse(path)[source]¶

Parser for sweet 16 measurement files. Only works for files younger than september 2013. Header files start with ‘#’ and are parsed in blocks. Each block starts with ‘#’+block_title+’‘.

Returns two dicitonaries. Header information is stored in ‘params’ dicitonary, data is stored in ‘data’ dictionary.

Converts the first two columns of sweet 16 data files (date, time) into two columns, ‘datetime’ in datetime format, and ‘time_numpy’ in float, which can be plotted directly by matplotlib.

Unit information is restored from data file and added to dictionary via quantities package.

Input parameters:

path: ‘string’ file path to valid sweet 16 file

Output parameters:

data: ‘dict’ dictionary containing data params: ‘dict’ dictionary containing header information

as blocks (each block a dictionary)
parse_data(line, variables, path, linenum)[source]¶
e21.sweet16.loader.parse_commands(arguments)[source]¶

Parses the command line of a Sweet 16 measurement file and returns a dicitionary of command string.

Input parameters:

arguments: list, list of command string entries,
(like one line in S16 command_file.txt)
e21.sweet16.loader.parse_header(line, params, block_title)[source]¶

Parses header of sweet 16 files. Function is called within parse, but can be called seperately

input parameters:

line: ‘string’ line of data file params: ‘dict’ dictionary, empty dictionary containing

only one key, value pair: params[block_title] = {}

block_title:’string’ initial block tile

output:

params: ‘dict’ containing header information
(key, value pair)of this line, stored in params[block_title][kw] = argument
block_title ‘string’ new block title if line defines new
block in data file, i.e. ‘#’+block_title+’’ (no argument)

e21.sweet16.spintorque_utility.chi_B(Data, Data_im, T=28.0, offset=0, y_out='real', plot_3d=False, delta=False, **kwargs)[source]¶

Produces a plot of Chi vs. Magnetic Field

Takes a Dictionary containing various grids of data for different currents. Checks which currents are available in grid.
Parameters:
  • Grids (dict) – Dictionary, output of make_grid()
  • Grids_imag (dict) – Dictionary, output of make_grid() usually Grids
  • T (float) – Temperature
  • B (list) – List of Field values at which to evaluate Chi Vs I
  • B_min (float) – Lower boundary of comparison region
  • B_max (float) – Upper boundary of comparison region
  • full_out (bool) – False returns the minimal res and the corresponding ind,True returns all residua

e21.sweet16.spintorque_utility.find_index(Grids, value, parameter='fields', current=0)[source]¶

Returns the index closest to the given field at a given current in a given Grid

E.g.:

path = '/Your_Path/'
MnSi_T = e21.sweet16.susceptibility.Experiment()
MnSi_T.add_measurements(sorted(glob.glob(path+'*.dat'),
                        key=os.path.getmtime))
find_field_index(MnSi_T[0].field, 2)
Parameters:
  • Grids (list) – Dictionary, output of make_grid()
  • Grids – Arabitrary measurement, eg. Exp[meas].field
  • value (float) – Value to look for closest index
  • parameter (str) – ‘fields’ or ‘temps’, irrelevant if Grids is list
Return (int):

Returns index
e21.sweet16.spintorque_utility.find_res(Grids, Grids_zero, T=28, current=0.0, B_min=0, B_max=0.55, full_out=False)[source]¶

Finds residuum of two curves.

Compares a Bsweep at given T and 0 A stored in Grids_zero with a Bsweep stored in Grids at T and I in the region between B_min and B_max. Returns the residuum of the two best fitting curves and the corresponding index. If full_out is True, then returns the residua of the difference between every curve at I and the curve at I = 0.

E.g.:

path = '/Your_Path/'
MnSi_T = e21.sweet16.susceptibility.Experiment()
MnSi_T.add_measurements(sorted(glob.glob(path+'*.dat'),
                               key=os.path.getmtime))
meas = get_current_meas(MnSi_T, 0)
g, c = make_grid(MnSi_T, meas)
Grids[c] = g
res, ind = find_res(Grids)
Parameters:
  • Grids (dict) – Dictionary, output of make_grid()
  • Grids_zero (dict) – Dictionary, output of make_grid()
  • T (float) – Temperature at which to compare Tsweeps
  • I (float) – Current of sweeps to compare with zero current sweeps
  • B_min (float) – Lower boundary of comparison region
  • B_max (float) – Upper boundary of comparison region
  • full_out (bool) – False returns the minimal res and the corresponding ind,True returns all residua
Return (float, int):
 

Returns the residuum and the corresponding index
e21.sweet16.spintorque_utility.find_sweep(Grids, value, parameter='fields', current=0)[source]¶

Find a certain B odr T sweep in the Grids dictionary

E.g.:

path = '/Your_Path/'
MnSi_T = e21.sweet16.susceptibility.Experiment()
MnSi_T.add_measurements(sorted(glob.glob(path+'*.dat'),
                               key=os.path.getmtime))
meas = [0,1,2,3]
g, c = make_grid(MnSi_T, meas)
Grids[c] = g
find_sweep(Grids, 1, parameter = 'fields')
Parameters:
  • Grids (dict) – Dictionary, output of make_grid()
  • value (float) – Value at which sweep was performed
  • parameter (str) – ‘fields’ for Tsweep or ‘temps’ for Bsweep
  • current (float) – Current at which to look for
Return (list):

Returns corresponding sweep
e21.sweet16.spintorque_utility.get_all_Tshifts(Grids, Grids_zero, I=[], T=28, B_min=0.49, B_max=0.55)[source]¶

gets the temperature shifts for different currents

Parameters:
  • Grids (dict) – Dictionary, output of make_grid()
  • T (float) – Temperature at which to compare Bsweeps
  • I (list) – list of currents
  • B_min (float) – Lower boundary of comparison region
  • B_max (float) – Upper boundary of comparison region
Return (list):

List of temperature differences
e21.sweet16.spintorque_utility.get_current(Exp, meas, tol=0.01)[source]¶

Returns current of a list of measurement.

Exception raised if measurements have different currents.

E.g.::plot_grid

path = ‘/Your_Path/’ MnSi_T = e21.sweet16.susceptibility.Experiment() MnSi_T.add_measurements(sorted(glob.glob(path+’*.dat’),

key=os.path.getmtime))

current, current_string = get_current(MnSi_T, meas)

Parameters:
  • Exp (dict) – sweet16 Experiment class dictionary
  • meas (list) – list of numbers of desired measurements
  • tol (float) – Tolerance in which all currents have to be equal
Raises:

ValueError, Measuremetns don’t have the same current within tol
Return (float, str):
 

current of measurements as float and string, (e.g. ‘0.0 A’) returns ‘0.0 A’ if current atrribute not available
e21.sweet16.spintorque_utility.get_current_meas(Exp, current)[source]¶

Returns a list of measurement numbers with given current.

E.g.:

path = '/Your_Path/'
MnSi_T = e21.sweet16.susceptibility.Experiment()
MnSi_T.add_measurements(sorted(glob.glob(path+'*.dat'),
                        key=os.path.getmtime))
meas = get_current_meas(MnSi_T, 1.0)
Parameters:
  • Exp (dict) – Sweet 16 Experiment class
  • current (float) – Current

:rtype list :return (list): List of measurements

e21.sweet16.spintorque_utility.get_temperature_shift(Grids, Grids_zero, I=0.0, T=28, B_min=0.49, B_max=0.55)[source]¶

gets the temperature shift of two sweeps at same Temperature but different currents

Parameters:
  • Grids (dict) – Dictionary, output of make_grid()
  • T (float) – Temperature at which to compare Bsweeps
  • I (float) – Current of sweep to compare with zero current sweep
  • B_min (float) – Lower boundary of comparison region
  • B_max (float) – Upper boundary of comparison region
Return (float):

Returns temperature shift
e21.sweet16.spintorque_utility.get_valid_currents(Grids)[source]¶

Returns all valid currents in Grids

e21.sweet16.spintorque_utility.lookup(obj, name)[source]¶

Helper function to provide function and string lookup of attributes.

E.g.:

>>>class Test(object):
...    pass
>>>t = Test()
>>>t.value = 'myvalue'
>>>lookup(t, 'value')
myvalue
>>>lookup(t, lambda x: x.value)
myvalue
>>lookup(t, [1, 2, 3])
[1, 2, 3]
e21.sweet16.spintorque_utility.make_grid(Exp, meas=[], data='real', min_y=0, max_y=0.6, scaling=[-1, 0], N=400j, **kwargs)[source]¶

Creates an extended grid for 2D plotting of Data.

The desired data set is interpolated on a regular gird of size (NxN). X and Y axis of the grid temperature and magnetic field. The date can be chosen freely.

E.g.:

path = '/Your_Path/'
MnSi_T = e21.sweet16.susceptibility.Experiment()
MnSi_T.add_measurements(sorted(glob.glob(path+'*.dat'),
                               key=os.path.getmtime))
meas = [0,1,2,3]
g, c = make_grid(MnSi_T, meas)
Grids[c] = g
Parameters:
  • Exp (dict) – sweet16 Experiment class
  • meas (list) – list of measurements
  • data (str,callable) – Desired Measurement data (property of Susc. Measurement), e.g. ‘imag’ or callable
  • min_y (float) – min field value
  • max_y (float) – max field value
  • scaling (list) – scaling factors m, b (m*x+ b) of data
  • N (complex) – Gridsize (NxN)
Kwargs:
  • min_x (float) - Lower x limit
  • max_x (float) - Upper x limit
Return (dict, str):
 

Returns a dictionary containing:

  • temps: list of temperature values
  • ‘grid’: actual grid
  • ‘fields’:list of field values
e21.sweet16.spintorque_utility.mark_critical_current(I=0.426, pos=0.1)[source]¶

Places a dashed line in plot at I with name Ic

Parameters:
  • I (float) – Critical current
  • pos (float) – Horizontal position of Text in percent of total height
e21.sweet16.spintorque_utility.plot_anpassung_auto(Grids, Grids_zero, T=28, current=0.0, B_min=0, B_max=0.55)[source]¶

e21.sweet16.spintorque_utility.plot_data(Exp, meas=[], data='real', scaling=-1, N=400j, nbins=4, legopts=[], **kwargs)[source]¶

Plots a set of data which corresponds to make_grid() function as a probe.

Usually only used together with make_grid()

E.g.:

path = '/Your_Path/'
MnSi_T = e21.sweet16.susceptibility.Experiment()
MnSi_T.add_measurements(sorted(glob.glob(path+'*.dat'),
                               key=os.path.getmtime))
meas = [0,1,2,3]
plot_data(MnSi_T, meas)
Parameters:
  • Exp (dict) – Sweet 16 Experiment class dictionary
  • meas (list) – List of measurements
  • scaling (float) – Scales the susceptibility with the factor scaling
  • N (complex) – Gridsize of corresponding grid
  • nbins (int) – Number of bins in plot
  • legopts (str) –
    • ‘small’: Small legend (min and max value) within plot
    • ‘short’: Smmall legend (min, max) outside of plot
    • ‘remove’: no legend
Kwargs:
  • cmap (callable) - Colormap instance
  • min_x (float) - minimum field value
  • max_x (float) - maximum field value
e21.sweet16.spintorque_utility.plot_grid(Grids, current, vmin=0, vmax=1e-06, nbins=4, **kwargs)[source]¶
Makes a 2D Contourplot of a given Grid. The input grid has
to be stored in a dicitionary (result of make_grid)

E.g.:

path = '/Your_Path/'
MnSi_T = e21.sweet16.susceptibility.Experiment()
MnSi_T.add_measurements(sorted(glob.glob(path+'*.dat'),
                               key=os.path.getmtime))
meas = [0,1,2,3]
g, c = make_grid_real(MnSi_T, meas)
Grids[c] = g
current = 0.0 # enter your measurement current here
plot_grid(Grids, current)
Parameters:
  • Grids (dict) – Dicitonary containing a grid of data as well as x and y axis values (result of make_grid)
  • current (float) – current of measurements to plot
  • vmin (float) – min susceptiblity value
  • vamx (float) – max susceptiblity value
  • nbins (float) – number of bins
Kwargs:
  • cmap (callable) - Colormap instance
  • clabel (str) - Colorbar label
  • cbin (int) - Number of bins on colorbar
  • remove_cb (bool) - If True, removes colorbar
